newsitem.title: USA: San Francisco Bay bridge funding talks break down.
newsitem.headline: San Francisco Bay bridge funding talks break down.

text.p: California Gov. Pete Wilson has withdrawn his offer to provide $500 million of state highway funds to help pay for the replacement and retrofit of San Francisco Bay area bridges, a spokesman for the governor said Thursday.
The Republican governor had offered to provide the $500 million in state highway funds as part of a $1.15 billion package to retrofit several toll bridges in northern California in need of repair.

But Wilson spokesman Sean Walsh said Thursday that talks between the Wilson administration and Senate President Pro Tem Bill Lockyer, a Democrat, over bridge funding broke down and that the governor's $500 million offer has been withdrawn.
Walsh said the governor withdrew from negotiations because Lockyer had demanded that Wilson increase the amount of state highway funds for the projects.

"The governor believes that his ($500 million state highway funds) offer is the most realistic, balanced, and politically viable option when weighed against the demands placed upon the state's roads, bridges, and infrastructure," Walsh said.
